physDesc.p: There are also a number of other emendations and additions by the Tremulous Hand of Worcester.

A single Latin marginal annotation on 39r in caroline miniscule may be the work of the scribe Coleman, at work elsewhere in Hatton 113, though the annotation has here been marked 'uncertain' for lack of strong enough evidence in favour of this assignment.

handNote.p: Ker's scribe 'O'. The scribe Wulfgeat. A round Anglo-Saxon miniscule. A slight lean to the right. Round, unroofed a; a mixture of descending insular long s and tall s; round d with short ascender that usually has a small flick or curve to the upper-right at its tip. Ash is of oe-form, with o always somewhat smaller, sometimes with tall e. e is horned, with a short tongue and a squinting eye. Ascenders of tall letters are wedged, leaning towards forking; thorn is noticeably forked. a is quite rounded in form.

An addending hand generally using a somewhat more finely-cut pen. The hand is marked by its tendency to leave a small gap at the top of e and fondness for an upwardly-curling long tongue on e. This hand sometimes adds interlinear Latin glosses or 'vel'-alternatives in other homilies. The same hand can be seen in other places in Hatton 113, generally inserting words either by extending the descender of a letter downward to mark the intended insertion area, or using a double-punctus marking.
